items.title: Spike in dolphin deaths at Huon Aquaculture pens prompts questions from Tasmanian regulator
items.summary: Tasmanian regulators question major salmon farm operator Huon Aquaculture about the effectiveness of its "predator" nets after a spate of dolphin deaths.

items.title: City of Melbourne rejects Mildura's attempt to return 'Yellow Peril' home
items.summary: City of Melbourne rejects Mildura's attempt to take the city's controversial "Yellow Peril" sculpture.

items.title: Renewable energy 'spilled' as generation outgrows demand
items.summary: Mountains of clean power are regularly "wasted" as Australia's energy system evolves. But a large amount of battery storage is waiting in the wings, ready to soak it up.

items.title: Albury's Macquarie Textiles celebrated for decades of manufacturing
items.summary: Textile manufacturing took Albury's work to the Opera House, federal parliament, the Olympics and beyond.

items.title: A letter to Anthony Albanese could allow Labor MPs to speak up on gambling reform
items.summary: Andrew Wilkie has asked the PM to allow a free vote on banning gambling advertising and it appears many Labor MPs would support it.

items.title: Chinese-made electric buses on Australian roads spark cybersecurity concerns after Norway flags issue
items.summary: The same Chinese company that makes electric buses now under review in Denmark and Norway also has electric buses on Australian roads.

items.title: Oscar Piastri says he still has what it takes to win F1 world championship
items.summary: Oscar Piastri has said he is still a serious contender for the Formula 1 world championship despite seeing his lead evaporate over the past five races.

items.title: High-speed rail business case linking Sydney and Newcastle supported by government assessment body
items.summary: The business case for high-speed rail between Sydney and Newcastle identifies four initial station locations for a one-hour journey.

items.title: Family of Australian man accused of cocaine smuggling speak ahead of possible Bali death sentence
items.summary: The sister of Australian man Lamar Ahchee, who has been on trial on drug charges in Bali, describes the moment she heard the news of his arrest.

items.title: Sorry seems to be the hardest word for ACT Transport Minister Chris Steel after bungled MyWay+ rollout
items.summary: Five days after being censured in the ACT's Legislative Assembly for the bungled rollout of the territory's MyWay+ network, Transport Minister Chris Steel has issued a statement to "apologise to anyone impacted by the transition to the new service".

items.title: NSW Police, WA Police and AFP charge 18 people in Strike Force Bloomfield drug bust
items.summary: Police charge 18 people in Perth and Sydney and seize 268 kilograms of illicit drugs following a multi-agency investigation into a national crime syndicate.

items.title: Calls for football clubs to divest from pokies with more than $110 million lost to machines
items.summary: There are calls for football teams to distance themselves from poker machines after data found more than $110 million was lost at venues owned by football clubs and leagues in the last financial year.

items.title: Plan to apply commercial council rates for short-stay rentals sparks debate
items.summary: A council in South Australia wants to charge short-stay rentals such as Airbnbs at a higher rate, saying they act as businesses.

items.title: Fishers and researchers are working together to create a 'transformational' data set
items.summary: An international program in which researchers collaborate with the fishing industry is generating a dataset that will change global weather forecasting.

items.title: A game for the ages: Nan and teen granddaughter line up together in country netball
items.summary: A grandmother and granddaughter played for their regional Victorian netball team, turning a secret plan into a moment of country sport history.

items.title: Horse racing replays edited to remove falls and deaths as industry grapples with social licence
items.summary: For years, the racing industry has been quietly removing falls and deaths from its replays. Now, industry insiders are speaking out.

items.title: The Canberra Liberals need to put their internal feud behind them. It's hard to see how they'll do that
items.summary: After suspending two backbenchers from her party room this week, Canberra Liberals leader Leanne Castley has been silent. And it's hard to see how staying silent is helping Canberrans build trust in her party and her as the ACT's alternative chief minister.

items.title: Donald Trump’s war on drugs targets Venezuela
items.summary: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

items.title: Donald Trump's campaign against Venezuelan drug boats is rooted in past failure and a hatred of Nicolas Maduro
items.summary: Donald Trump is on a revenge tour during his second stint in the White House and now his gaze has shifted to an enemy who once "humiliated" him — Nicolas Maduro.

items.title: Socceroos coach Tony Popovic says restoring Australia's football DNA is key to creating World Cup history
items.summary: The Socceroos have historically been seen as plucky underdogs at the FIFA World Cup. Now, Tony Popovic believes those same traits can see his side create history.

items.title: Brazil's deadliest ever police operation leaves at least 120 dead after Rio de Janeiro drug raid
items.summary: Brazil's deadliest ever police operation has triggered protests against the use of excessive force and calls for Rio's governor to resign.

items.title: Oyster farmers blockade trucks carrying oysters from algal bloom waters
items.summary: Oyster farmers have formed a blockade at Haslam in South Australia to prevent oysters from an area affected by the algal bloom being put in the waters around Streaky Bay.

items.title: Caravan street parking solution stifled by council red tape, storage owners say
items.summary: A Queensland council struggling to solve a caravan street parking crisis is hampered by its own planning laws, a storage business says.

items.title: Dicky Beach holiday park residents angry after Sunshine Coast Council decision
items.summary: More than 100 residents face an uncertain future after a Queensland council votes to end permanent residencies at a holiday park.

items.title: The key role a 'lost' reef is playing in South Australia's algal bloom fight
items.summary: A marine ecologist's discovery two years ago sparked a restoration project and has become a key element in South Australia's response to a devastating algal bloom.

items.title: NSW government's drug summit response rejects medicinal cannabis defence for drivers for now
items.summary: The government says it was "investigating" a medical defence for drivers prescribed cannabis but ruled out the use of sniffer dogs and strip searches for suspected drug possession at music festivals in its response to last year's drug summit.

items.title: Walking netball adaptation helping players stay on the court
items.summary: Before they take the court, the Magnolias strap on knee braces and tie bows in their hair. But don't be deceived, they're playing one of the 'most competitive games', and there may be elbows thrown.

items.title: Newcastle mother calls for tougher laws after toddler run down by e-bike
items.summary: More than a year after her 21-month-old child was hit by an e-bike, a Newcastle mother is calling for change.

items.title: What we know about 'mind-boggling' NBA rigging and poker fraud cases
items.summary: The allegations involve NBA luminaries, multiple New York mafia families, millions in cash and even an x-ray poker table that could read cards face down.

items.title: Australia is all in on AUKUS. In Donald Trump's America, it's more complicated
items.summary: In Washington on Monday, Anthony Albanese made something clear once again: Australia is all-in on the trilateral defence pact. Clarifying what US powerbrokers think remains a multi-billion-dollar question.

items.title: Mate Stipinovich, Aristides Avlontis, Karl Whitburn jailed for bungled Albany drug smuggling attempt
items.summary: Three men forced to cling to an esky to survive in wild seas off Albany as they tried to import hundreds of kilograms of cocaine into Western Australia are described by a judge as "Keystone criminals" at their sentencing.

items.title: NT politicians call for inquiry into Australia's de facto online gambling regulator
items.summary: More than 40 of Australia's corporate bookmakers are based in the Northern Territory for its low taxes and what critics describe as weak regulation.

items.title: Survey finds majority of Victorian renters face problems — but not nearly as many lodge a complaint
items.summary: A survey of 1,000 Victorian renters finds nearly four in five households faced a tenancy issue over a 12-month period — but only half of them escalated the issue by lodging a complaint.

items.title: More than $6 million of cocaine and methylamphetamine seized during vehicle stop in southern NSW
items.summary: Highway patrol stopped the black luxury SUV on a major New South Wales highway for a random drug and alcohol test on Friday afternoon.

items.title: Albanese government's BetStop scheme not working, former gambler says
items.summary: Diehard Richmond fan "Tiger Shaun" says he's watched on in horror as gambling advertising and sponsorships have come to dominate football — and become a constant reminder of the addiction he has struggled with.

items.title: Las Vegas licence hearing turns nightmare for boss of Australian pokies giant
items.summary: Regulators in the world's most influential gaming jurisdiction have dismissed a licence bid by the boss of Australia's Ainsworth Game Technology, branding him "arrogant", "misleading" and lacking in "emotional intelligence".

items.title: Calls for national gambling watchdog grow amid NT conflict allegations
items.summary: The NT government is standing by its de-facto regulation of Australia’s $50 billion online gambling industry, despite allegations that it is too closely linked to the sector.

items.title: Gold price hits record high, topping $US4,000 an ounce for first time, amid US shutdown and lower interest rates
items.summary: The price of gold has hit another record and is set to become Australia's second most valuable resource export after iron ore.

items.title: Losing Streak
items.summary: Four Corners is the home of Australian investigative journalism.

items.title: Betting companies keep millions stolen from investors by 'VIP' gambler
items.summary: Nick and Aimee Mazza's hard-earned cash was gambled away by a man they thought was investing it. Bookmakers encouraged him to keep betting.

items.title: Southern pygmy perch 'ear bones' provide data to re-establish populations
items.summary: Information gleaned from tiny growth rings on "ear bones" of native pygmy perch could be the key to bringing them back from local extinction in the lower Murray.

items.title: Former A-League footballers Clayton Lewis and Kearyn Baccus sentenced over betting scam
items.summary: Both players were paid $10,000 each to intentionally get themselves yellow cards while playing for Macarthur FC against Sydney FC to influence overseas bets on the game.

items.title: Commonwealth Avenue Bridge upgrade likely to cause commuter chaos
items.summary: Major upgrades addressing the structural safety of the Commonwealth Avenue Bridge will soon begin, leading to two years of significant traffic disruption.

items.title: Robert Karl Huber sentenced over manslaughter of Lindy Lucena
items.summary: Robert Karl Huber is sentenced to 12 years in prison over the death of his partner Lindy Lucena in Ballina in 2023.

items.title: Nestory Irankunda returns to Socceroos squad after 10-month absence as Tony Popovic praises maturity
items.summary: Socceroos coach Tony Popovic praises Nestory Irankunda's maturity as he names the starlet in his squad for the first time this year ahead of the "Soccer Ashes" against New Zealand.

items.title: Traditional owners sign native title agreement for Agnew gold mine
items.summary: Tjiwarl Aboriginal Corporation meets with South African miner Gold Fields in Leinster to sign an agreement for one of the WA's oldest gold mines.

items.title: Ausgold acquires 860ha of farmland for Katanning Gold Project
items.summary: Ausgold's deal includes an 860-hectare land acquisition, as well as compensation and relocation of the farming families involved.

items.title: Heather Ewart reflects on the tough road to Back Roads success
items.summary: Heather Ewart was a powerhouse political reporter when she was asked to create a show about regional Australia. A decade later, and with her final season going to air, Ewart admits that getting the idea off the ground was no easy feat.

items.title: Mat Ryan wanted to freeze time on 100th appearance for Socceroos after penalty save
items.summary: The keeper said he felt like he had played his final Socceroos match when he was left out of the starting XI late last year. Now he's celebrated his 100th international with a fine penalty stop as Australia progressed to the FIFA World Cup.

items.title: What the Socceroos need against Saudi Arabia to qualify for the World Cup
items.summary: The Socceroos are just a solid performance from reaching their sixth FIFA World Cup finals in a row, but must remain focused against Saudi Arabia in Jeddah. Here's everything you need to know.

items.title: US demands Australia lifts defence spending by $40b a year 'as soon as possible'
items.summary: The United States wants Australia to lift spending on defence to about $100 billion a year, with its Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth warning of a "real and potentially imminent" threat from China.

items.title: Tennant Creek hopes gold mine reopening marks return to 'gold capital'
items.summary: As the first gold bars are poured at the reopened Nobles Nob gold mine in the Northern Territory, locals hope it will bring a return to the region's golden era.

items.title: Record gold price sees West Australian mine revived
items.summary: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

items.title: Tiwi Islanders eager to have their say as remote voting for the federal election begins
items.summary: Voters in the small remote community of Pirlangimpi on the Tiwi Islands, north of Darwin, have become some of the first to cast their votes for the federal election.

items.title: Next-generation voters call for better engagement ahead of federal election
items.summary: Young people in Albury say issues that directly affect them and their communities are not being addressed by major parties for the 2025 election campaign.

items.title: Graduates in 'debt vortex' as HECS front and centre for first time in an election
items.summary: New research shows a sharp rise in HECS debts, despite graduate earning power declining, as student loans become a potent election issue for the first time.

items.title: Australia's growing cohort of tenants fear they will rent forever
items.summary: Home ownership rates in Australia have been falling for decades, and with rental vacancies at record lows and prices at historic highs, many fear their dream of owning a home may be out of reach. Some experts say rental caps could help.

items.title: Push for seniors' dental scheme grows ahead of federal election
items.summary: Imagine living in aged care and not having your teeth or dentures properly cleaned and checked each day. That's a risk faced by elderly Australians, prompting calls for the next federal government to boost oral health training and services.

items.title: Betrayal of Trust: Australia's Childcare Crisis
items.summary: Four Corners is the home of Australian investigative journalism.

items.title: Underground compressed air energy storage facility green-lit at Broken Hill
items.summary: An old mine in Broken Hill will be re-purposed by Canadian company Hydrostor as an "innovative" renewable energy storage and generation project tipped to create hundreds of local construction jobs.

items.title: South Australian Liberals elect Vincent Tarzia as new leader to replace David Speirs
items.summary: South Australia's Liberal Party has elected Vincent Tarzia as its new leader, replacing David Speirs, who announced his resignation last week.

items.title: Banana industry turns to robots and AI for 'dangerous' packing-shed task of cutting fruit from stem
items.summary: It takes effort to get bananas from the farm to the fruit bowl, with growers relying on a significant workforce to pick and pack. Now scientists are working on technology to make it easier and safer.

items.title: Carnarvon banana growers using freeze-dried facility to save fruit rejected by Australian supermarkets
items.summary: Tonnes of West Australian bananas that would end up as waste or mulch are being made into freeze-dried snacks and used to make products like vodka as Carnarvon growers look to reduce wastage.

items.title: Hundreds of jobs on horizon after green light from Transgrid for Hydrostor's compressed-air energy storage in Broken Hill
items.summary: While the future of one of Broken Hill's major mines is still uncertain, a green energy storage project to be built in the coming years may provide employment opportunities for some of the displaced workers.

items.title: Update your ABC News homepage for more local stories
items.summary: We've got an ABC News homepage for you. Adjust your settings for the right mix of local and national news.

items.title: Ayers Rock Resort losing $3 million a month while it waits for tourists to return
items.summary: Ayers Rock Resort says it is losing millions of dollars of month while it waits for tourism to pick back up from the pandemic slumber.

items.title: Review questions Ayers Rock Resort valuation and buy by Indigenous Land Corporation
items.summary: An advisory group that delivered the highest valuation for central Australia's Ayers Rock Resort in 2010 was paid a fee based on the purchase price.

items.title: Dust flies in Ayers Rock Resort $65m writedown
items.summary: The Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) is making sweeping changes after writing off more than $62 million from the value of its flagship tourism property at Uluru. The Federally-funded corporation paid $317 million for the Ayers Rock Resort in 2010 but its value has now been written down to about $250 million.
